DataElement.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Clinical Tumor T Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the primary carcinoma of the vulva based on evidence obtained from clinical assessment parameters determined prior to treatment.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The external, visible part of the female genitalia surrounding the urethral and vaginal opening. The vulva includes the clitoris and inner as well as outer labia._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation. The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity._One criteria of the TMN staging system.  T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The external, visible part of the female genitalia surrounding the urethral and vaginal opening. The vulva includes the clitoris and inner as well as outer labia.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Concepts.definition: The external, visible part of the female genitalia surrounding the urethral and vaginal opening. The vulva includes the clitoris and inner as well as outer labia.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Having to do with the examination and treatment of patients.:One criteria of the TMN staging system.  T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

Concepts.definition: Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for CRF standard harmonization. Released per final community approval. mc 5/7/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 T Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A finding about one or more characteristics of vulvar cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system.  Vulvar cancer is a surgically staged malignancy. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)_A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._One criteria of the TMN staging system.  T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion)._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer pT0 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer pT0 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer with no evidence of primary tumor. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer pT0 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer with no evidence of primary tumor. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer pT1a TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer pT1a TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer with tumor size 2 cm or less, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion 1.0 mm or less.  The depth of invasion is defined as the measurement of the tumor from the epithelial-stromal junction of the adjacent most superficial dermal papilla to the deepest point of invasion.  (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer pT1a TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer with tumor size 2 cm or less, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion 1.0 mm or less.  The depth of invasion is defined as the measurement of the tumor from the epithelial-stromal junction of the adjacent most superficial dermal papilla to the deepest point of invasion.  (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer pT1b TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer pT1b TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer with tumor size greater than 2 cm, or any size with stromal invasion more than 1.0 mm, confined to the vulva or perineum. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer pT1b TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer with tumor size greater than 2 cm, or any size with stromal invasion more than 1.0 mm, confined to the vulva or perineum. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer pT2 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer pT2 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer with tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower/distal 1/3 urethra, lower/distal 1/3 vagina, anal involvement). (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer pT2 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer with tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower/distal 1/3 urethra, lower/distal 1/3 vagina, anal involvement). (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer pT3 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer pT3 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer with tumor of any size with extension to any of the following: upper/proximal 2/3 urethra, upper/proximal 2/3 vagina, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to pelvic bone. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer pT3 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer with tumor of any size with extension to any of the following: upper/proximal 2/3 urethra, upper/proximal 2/3 vagina, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to pelvic bone. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer pTis TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer pTis TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer with a finding of carcinoma in situ. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer pTis TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer with a finding of carcinoma in situ. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Vulvar Cancer pTX TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Vulvar Cancer pTX TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vulvar cancer in which the primary tumor cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Vulvar Cancer pTX TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Vulvar cancer in which the primary tumor cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A finding about one or more characteristics of vulvar cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system.  Vulvar cancer is a surgically staged malignancy. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)
A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).
The extent of a cancer in the body.
